citation.article-title: Desulfovibrio simplex spec. nov., a new sulfate-reducing bacterium from a sour whey digester

p.s: Description of Desulfovibrio simplex spe. nov., Zellner and Winter

Desulfovibrio simplex (De.- sul.fo.vi'bri.o.L, pref. de from; L. n. sulfur sulfur; L. v. vibrio to vibrate; M. L. masc. n. Vibrio that which vibrates, a generic name; M. L. masc. n. Desulfovibrio a vibrio-shaped microorganism that reduces sulfur compounds; sim.plex. M. L. masc. simplex meaning ordinary, simple, inconspicuous; Desulfovibrio simplex, an ordinary, inconspicuous vibrio-shaped sulfate reducing bacterium.
Curved, vibrioid rods, singly or in pairs, 0.5-1.0 μm x 1.5-3.0 μm in size.
Cells flagellated by a single, polar flagellum with a diameter of ca. 17 nm, log-phase cells vigorously motile.
Spore formation not observed.
Gram-stain negative, no S-layer.
Strictly anaerobic, chemolithotrophic and chemoorganotrophic.
Mesophilic with optimum temperature around 37°C range > 15°C and < 45°C Optimum pH around 7. 63Ni2+ and 185WO2-4 are incorporated into growing cells.
Strictly anaerobic metabolism by sulfate reduction.
Electron acceptors are SO2-4 and S2O2-3, not utilized is SO2-3.
NO-3 is utilized after adaptation.
L(+)-Lactate, pyruvate, fumarate, malate, formate, ethanol, 1-propanol, l-butanol and hydrogen serve as electron donors.
Growth on H2/CO2 only in the presence of yeast extract or acetate.
Not utilized are acetate, propiouate, n-butyrate, methanol, 2-propanol, 2-butanol, glycerol, succinate, citrate, choline, glucose, and fructose.
L(+)-Lactate is incompletely oxidized to acetate.
Acetate cannot be further oxidized.
Reducing equivalents are used for reduction of sulfate to hydrogen sulfide.
Besides growth on the classical substrates, little growth occurs on CO2 + vanillin, p-anisaldehyde or syringaldehyde by oxidation to the respective benzoic acids.
UV/VIS spectra of crude extracts reveal the spectrum of desulfoviridin with an absorption maximum at 630 nm.
Cells contain spermine and spermidine, whereas 1,3-diaminopropane and putrescine are present only in trace amounts.
Cadaverine and homologues of spermidine and spermine are absent.
The G+C content of DNA is 47.5 mol% (Tm).
The type strain of Desulfovibrio simplex spec. nov. is strain XVI and has been deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen (Braunschweig, FRG) under No. DSM 4141.
Strain XVI was isolated from an anaerobic digester for the biomethanation of sour whey originally inoculated with sewage sludge.
